posts.name: Skylar Taylor
posts.cooked: I think it would be really lovely to use Signal while driving via Siri. Right now if you want to use Signal in your car, you have to grab your phone and type on the screen, rather than simply spiking while driving.

link_counts.title: No notifications when using Apple CarPlay
Getting to 0 GitHub issues in Signal-iOS
Who is still thinking that our brand phones are not recording text on screens 24h a day?

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked: So you’re using a private messenger and then send all data to Apple? Doesn’t sound like a good idea to me. The same holds for Google.

posts.name: Skylar Taylor
posts.cooked:
You can literally do the same thing now if you want by pressing the speech to text button on the keyboard, so I don’t really see what the difference is from a security standpoint.

Right now for safety reasons I use iMessage over Signal when I’m in the car, which is less than ideal.

posts.name: Matt Vose
posts.cooked: I would like to see CarPlay support as well. WhatsApp is on CarPlay, along with the normal iMessage.

posts.name: Martin Straub
posts.cooked:
I would also love to see this feature

Why don’t let the users decide if they want to use a “insecure” feature for convenience? Maybe it’s possible to add a switch in the settings for disabling not “100%-secure” features? IDK, but there should be a solution for that as well?

From convenience point of view this would be lovely feature. From privacy point of view this is not the best idea, because Signal is working hard to be recognized as secure/private application and then implementing insecure/non-private features would degrade the reputation. Another point is developers time and effort spend on implementing this feature instead of other features on iOS-phone. Signal is still very small team and resources has to be carefully taken into consideration.
Umm…I never use Siri, Cortana, or any other audio recording device…

d4rkd3v1l:

Why don’t let the users decide if they want to use a “insecure” feature for convenience?

An aspect worth considering is, that it’s not only your data that’s handled insecure, but also other persons (your conversation partners) data. And unless you tell them beforehand, they have no chance to know (let alone prevent that) their data is handled insecure.

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
Seen at the general number of installs, I hope that installing Signal is not yet under “peer pressure”, but is mostly done consciously, i.e. you have decided for “privacy/security”
in the first place and not because of the simplicity, “attractive” design, …
As for my part, I hope that in the future development of Signal(app+services), the privacy/security will remain in first place and all “unsafe” features will not be implemented at all. Even if the usability would be negatively affected.

posts.name: Martin Straub
posts.cooked: Ok, you’re right. Didn’t think about the point, that I will also make others data insecure.

I know this sounds really trivial and insignificant to the security-focused crowd around Signal, but having Carplay would be a huge boost to the experience. Experience is everything with messaging apps, and i think Carplay integration could make a huge difference here.

iMessage obviously supports it, as does Whatsapp. Latest Telegram beta introduced carplay support. I really think Signal should be up there

posts.name: Kyle
posts.cooked:
I think there’s a safe way to implement CarPlay if you still want to maintain a privacy focus. It might not be ideal, but you could perhaps disable the ability for messages to be read to the user by CarPlay and only allow for messages to simply be sent. That way only the user who chooses to use Siri is being insecure (by using Siri voice-to-text in that regard), and all message content inside the app is still secure.

I don’t know the technical implementations of something like this, but the idea seems like it might be worth investigating?

The lack of CarPlay support is unfortunate when compared to the competition. I really want to use Signal as my primary method of contacting non iMessage users, but Telegram is far more integrated with iOS/Mac OS. Beyond missing CarPlay, the desktop app doesn’t support Touch ID, which once again, the competition does

posts.name: Nathan B
posts.cooked:
This would be a big +1 from me.

Im in the process of moving across to Signal from WhatsApp, and the lack of Carplay support is a big negative.

To be able to simply say “Send Signal to my wife, I’ll be home in 10 minutes” is a big convenience.

I can understand from a privacy implication why reading messages might be an issue, but a basic send command would go a long way.

I have been pondering this for some time - and agree it would be useful.

I have read through the thread regarding the privacy issue and @kgsbowtie makes a good point RE only allowing ‘Sent’.

I confess, I do not know how this type of request would work or how Signal / Apple would require data. But surely Apple doesn’t need to read the data (already in your Signal messages), but merely a command to open a message box and input the text? I recognise that is a very coarse view of it, but am I missing something here?

posts.name: Signal Noise
posts.cooked: Even if Signal decided not to enable messages to be read though Carplay (for aforementioned privacy reasons), I would appreciate being able to use Siri on Carplay if only to initiate VOIP calls. At present, I have to find the app on my phone to initiate a call to Signal users. Thankfully, I can easily end the call on Carplay. Before migrating from Whatsapp to Signal, I was able to easily initiate VOIP calls with Siri while driving places. This functionality is sorely missed!

posts.name: François-Xavier Payet
posts.cooked:
The privacy argument is kind of hypocritical here, as you can already hear message from other people on Android Auto. So there’s really no argument toward not implementing CarPlay, except for the lack of time from developers. If that’s the case that’s a different issue, but otherwise I really don’t understand why we don’t already have CarPlay support. It’s a big big lack of functionality for Signal.
And for those that don’t want it, you can disable any app you want on CarPlay, so again not an argument.

posts.name: Josh Hubbard
posts.cooked: I agree with @foux974 that the argument is hypocritical since android users already have this feature. I’m taking upon myself to write a CarPlay solution. Once I get a codebase up I’ll share a link if anybody wants to contribute.
Android auto can only read a notification. There’s no Signal app or anything.

posts.name: Josh Hubbard
posts.cooked: Well, time for somebody to write one :P. I’ll start on CarPlay.
